H0.text: No lungs are why fish have short esophaguses.

H1.text: Big tail is why fish have short esophaguses.

H2.text: No intestines are the reason fish have short esophaguses.

H3.text: No mouths are the reason fish have short esophaguses.

A4.text: lampreys, hagfishes, chimaeras, lungfishes, and some teleost fish have no stomach at all, with the esophagus opening directly into the intestine.

A5.text: There is no small intestine as such in non-teleost fish, such as sharks, sturgeons, and lungfish. Instead, the digestive part of the gut forms a spiral intestine, connecting the stomach to the rectum.

A7.text: Fish ingest food through the mouth and break it down in the esophagus.

A8.text: The small intestine is a tubular structure around 6 to 7 m long.

A9.text: Bichirs and lungfish have tetrapod-like paired lungs, requiring them to surface to gulp air, and making them obligate air breathers.

A10.text: The digestive system consists of a tube, the gut, leading from the mouth to the anus.
